Stat 204, Advent 2021
  • Syllabus
  • Homework
  • Matthew Rudd

Syllabus


We are constantly bombarded by data and by claims about data – it has never been more important to be able to distinguish between the sensible claims and the preposterous ones. Data literacy and statistical competence are therefore essential skills, and this course aims to help you develop them. Instead of working with contrived datasets, we’ll tackle some messy real-world data head on, and you’ll learn the tools you need to answer realistic questions. These skills will help you in future courses, in your jobs, and in your lives as citizens of a complicated world. After taking this course, you should be able to analyze data for yourself to obtain meaningful insights and to make decisions that you can defend.

We will work through chapters 1 through 9 of the book, devoting 3 classes to each chapter:

  • I will mostly lecture for the first class on each chapter,
  • you will present homework and we’ll discuss the rest of the chapter in the second class, and
  • you will work in pairs on a mini-project in the third class.

To get the most out of this experience and contribute your share, you must

  • stay caught up with the readings and assignments,
  • work together within the parameters of the Honor Code, and
  • talk to me whenever you have questions.

If you don’t understand something, get help immediately!

Textbook

  • Statistics With R by Jenine K. Harris

Software

We will use the following to analyze and visualize data:

  • R and RStudio
  • Google Sheets

We will also use Zoom to share screens in class and to accommodate anyone who needs to quarantine:

  • Zoom link
  • meeting ID: 873 7070 0567

Times & location

  • Tuesdays and Thursdays, Woods Labs 216
    • Section C: 9:30 a.m.-10:45 a.m. CST
    • Section D: 11:00 a.m.-12:15 p.m. CST

Homework, exams, and grading

To help all of you develop your data analysis skills, gain experience communicating technical results, and practice for exams, you will present your work regularly and pair up with other students on in-class mini-projects. There will be 2 exams, and your scores on these components will contribute to your final grade as follows:

  • Homework: 25%
  • In-class projects: 25%
  • Exams (2): 25% each

Honor Code

As a Sewanee student, you have already sworn to uphold the Honor Code; I expect you to comport yourself accordingly. Work with your classmates to understand the course material, but submit work that is truly your own. You must not consult with other students when taking exams or quizzes. In addition to avoiding a guilty conscience, you’ll learn more this way anyhow!

Attendance

Missing class seriously undermines the educational process, so be responsible and don’t do it unless absolutely necessary.

Special needs

Please notify me immediately if you have any documented special needs that need to be accommodated. The University’s official ADA statement may be helpful in this regard:

The University of the South is committed to fostering respect for the diversity of the University community and the individual rights of each member of that community. In this spirit, and in accordance with the provisions of Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the University seeks to provide students with disabilities with the reasonable accommodations needed to ensure equal access to the programs and activities of the University.

Any student with a documented disability needing academic adjustments is requested to speak with Student Accessibility Services (SAS) as early in the semester as possible. If approved for accommodations, the student has the responsibility to present their instructors with a copy of the official letter of academic accommodations. Please note: Accommodation letters should be dated for the current term; accommodations will not be provided without a current accommodation letter; and accommodations cannot be applied retroactively. SAS is located in the Office of the Dean of Students (931.598.1229). Additional information about accommodations can be found here. Students who have questions about physical accessibility should inform their instructors so that we can ensure an accessible, safe, and effective environment.
